titleInfo.title: COMMERCE, JUSTICE, SCIENCE, AND RELATED AGENCIES APPROPRIATIONS ACT, 2016

extension.searchTitle: COMMERCE, JUSTICE, SCIENCE, AND RELATED AGENCIES APPROPRIATIONS ACT, 2016; Congressional Record Vol. 162, No. 98

congVote.result: Three-fifths of the Senators duly chosen and sworn not having voted in the affirmative, the motion is rejected.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act_Agreement
Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act_Agreement
Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act_Agreement
Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act_Agreement
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: Senate resumed consideration of H.R. 2578, making appropriations for the Departments of Commerce and Justice, Science, and Related Agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2016, taking action on the following amendments proposed thereto:<P/>Shelby/Mikulski Amendment No. 4685, in the nature of a substitute.<P/>McConnell (for McCain) Amendment No. 4787 (to Amendment No. 4685), to amend section 2709 of title 18, United States Code, to clarify that the Government may obtain a specified set of electronic communication transactional records under that section, and to make permanent the authority for individual terrorists to be treated as agents of foreign powers under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978.<P/>McConnell motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Appropriations for a period of 14 days.<P/>A motion was entered to close further debate on McConnell (for McCain) Amendment No. 4787 (to Amendment No. 4685), and, in accordance with the provisions of rule XXII of the Standing Rules of the Senate, a vote on cloture will occur on Wednesday, June 22, 2016.<P/>During consideration of this measure today, Senate also took the following action:<P/>By 53 yeas to 47 nays (Vote No. 103), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750) (listed below).<P/>By 44 yeas to 56 nays (Vote No. 104), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell motion to commit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions, (McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750) (listed above).<P/>By 53 yeas to 47 nays (Vote No. 105), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Cornyn) Amendment No. 4749 (to Amendment No. 4720) (listed below).<P/>By 47 yeas to 53 nays (Vote No. 106), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Feinstein) Amendment No. 4720 (to Amendment No. 4685) (listed above).<P/>McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750, to ensure that all individuals who should be prohibited from buying a firearm are listed in the national instant criminal background check system and require a background check for every firearm sale, fell when McConnell motion to commit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions, was tabled.

Senate resumed consideration of H.R. 2578, making appropriations for the Departments of Commerce and Justice, Science, and Related Agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2016, taking action on the following amendments proposed thereto:<P/>Shelby/Mikulski Amendment No. 4685, in the nature of a substitute.<P/>McConnell (for McCain) Amendment No. 4787 (to Amendment No. 4685), to amend section 2709 of title 18, United States Code, to clarify that the Government may obtain a specified set of electronic communication transactional records under that section, and to make permanent the authority for individual terrorists to be treated as agents of foreign powers under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978.<P/>McConnell motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Appropriations for a period of 14 days.<P/>A motion was entered to close further debate on McConnell (for McCain) Amendment No. 4787 (to Amendment No. 4685), and, in accordance with the provisions of rule XXII of the Standing Rules of the Senate, a vote on cloture will occur on Wednesday, June 22, 2016.<P/>During consideration of this measure today, Senate also took the following action:<P/>By 53 yeas to 47 nays (Vote No. 103), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750) (listed below).<P/>By 44 yeas to 56 nays (Vote No. 104), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell motion to commit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions, (McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750) (listed above).<P/>By 53 yeas to 47 nays (Vote No. 105), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Cornyn) Amendment No. 4749 (to Amendment No. 4720) (listed below).<P/>By 47 yeas to 53 nays (Vote No. 106), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Feinstein) Amendment No. 4720 (to Amendment No. 4685) (listed above).<P/>McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750, to ensure that all individuals who should be prohibited from buying a firearm are listed in the national instant criminal background check system and require a background check for every firearm sale, fell when McConnell motion to commit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions, was tabled.<P/>McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750), to address gun violence and improve the availability of records to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System, fell when McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750, fell.

Senate resumed consideration of H.R. 2578, making appropriations for the Departments of Commerce and Justice, Science, and Related Agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2016, taking action on the following amendments proposed thereto:<P/>Shelby/Mikulski Amendment No. 4685, in the nature of a substitute.<P/>McConnell (for McCain) Amendment No. 4787 (to Amendment No. 4685), to amend section 2709 of title 18, United States Code, to clarify that the Government may obtain a specified set of electronic communication transactional records under that section, and to make permanent the authority for individual terrorists to be treated as agents of foreign powers under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978.<P/>McConnell motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Appropriations for a period of 14 days.<P/>A motion was entered to close further debate on McConnell (for McCain) Amendment No. 4787 (to Amendment No. 4685), and, in accordance with the provisions of rule XXII of the Standing Rules of the Senate, a vote on cloture will occur on Wednesday, June 22, 2016.<P/>During consideration of this measure today, Senate also took the following action:<P/>By 53 yeas to 47 nays (Vote No. 103), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750) (listed below).<P/>By 44 yeas to 56 nays (Vote No. 104), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell motion to commit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions, (McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750) (listed above).<P/>By 53 yeas to 47 nays (Vote No. 105), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Cornyn) Amendment No. 4749 (to Amendment No. 4720) (listed below).<P/>By 47 yeas to 53 nays (Vote No. 106), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Feinstein) Amendment No. 4720 (to Amendment No. 4685) (listed above).<P/>McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750, to ensure that all individuals who should be prohibited from buying a firearm are listed in the national instant criminal background check system and require a background check for every firearm sale, fell when McConnell motion to commit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions, was tabled.<P/>McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750), to address gun violence and improve the availability of records to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System, fell when McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750, fell.<P/>McConnell Amendment No. 4752 (to Amendment No. 4751), to change the enactment date, fell when McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750) (listed above) fell.

Senate resumed consideration of H.R. 2578, making appropriations for the Departments of Commerce and Justice, Science, and Related Agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2016, taking action on the following amendments proposed thereto:<P/>Shelby/Mikulski Amendment No. 4685, in the nature of a substitute.<P/>McConnell (for McCain) Amendment No. 4787 (to Amendment No. 4685), to amend section 2709 of title 18, United States Code, to clarify that the Government may obtain a specified set of electronic communication transactional records under that section, and to make permanent the authority for individual terrorists to be treated as agents of foreign powers under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978.<P/>McConnell motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Appropriations for a period of 14 days.<P/>A motion was entered to close further debate on McConnell (for McCain) Amendment No. 4787 (to Amendment No. 4685), and, in accordance with the provisions of rule XXII of the Standing Rules of the Senate, a vote on cloture will occur on Wednesday, June 22, 2016.<P/>During consideration of this measure today, Senate also took the following action:<P/>By 53 yeas to 47 nays (Vote No. 103), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750) (listed below).<P/>By 44 yeas to 56 nays (Vote No. 104), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell motion to commit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions, (McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750) (listed above).<P/>By 53 yeas to 47 nays (Vote No. 105), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Cornyn) Amendment No. 4749 (to Amendment No. 4720) (listed below).<P/>By 47 yeas to 53 nays (Vote No. 106), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Feinstein) Amendment No. 4720 (to Amendment No. 4685) (listed above).<P/>McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750, to ensure that all individuals who should be prohibited from buying a firearm are listed in the national instant criminal background check system and require a background check for every firearm sale, fell when McConnell motion to commit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions, was tabled.<P/>McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750), to address gun violence and improve the availability of records to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System, fell when McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750, fell.<P/>McConnell Amendment No. 4752 (to Amendment No. 4751), to change the enactment date, fell when McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750) (listed above) fell.<P/>McConnell (for Cornyn) Amendment No. 4749 (to Amendment No. 4720), to Secure our Homeland from radical Islamists by Enhancing Law enforcement Detection (''SHIELD''), fell when Senate tabled McConnell (for Feinstein) Amendment No. 4720 (to Amendment No. 4685).

yeas to 47 nays (Vote No. 103), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750) (listed below).<P/>By 44 yeas to 56 nays (Vote No. 104), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell motion to commit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions, (McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750) (listed above).<P/>By 53 yeas to 47 nays (Vote No. 105), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Cornyn) Amendment No. 4749 (to Amendment No. 4720) (listed below).<P/>By 47 yeas to 53 nays (Vote No. 106), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Feinstein) Amendment No. 4720 (to Amendment No. 4685) (listed above).<P/>McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750, to ensure that all individuals who should be prohibited from buying a firearm are listed in the national instant criminal background check system and require a background check for every firearm sale, fell when McConnell motion to commit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions, was tabled.<P/>McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750), to address gun violence and improve the availability of records to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System, fell when McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750, fell.

Amendment No. 4750, to ensure that all individuals who should be prohibited from buying a firearm are listed in the national instant criminal background check system and require a background check for every firearm sale, fell when McConnell motion to commit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions, was tabled.<P/>McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the No. 4750, fell.<P/>McConnell Amendment No. 4752 (to Amendment No. 4751), to change the enactment date, fell when McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750) congVote.result: Three-fifths of the Senators duly chosen and sworn not having voted in the affirmative, the motion is rejected.

Amendment No. 4750, to ensure that all individuals who should be prohibited from buying a firearm are listed in the national instant criminal background check system and require a background check for every firearm sale, fell when McConnell motion to commit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions, was tabled.<P/>McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750), to address gun violence and improve the availability of records to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System, fell when McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750, fell.<P/>McConnell Amendment No. 4752 (to Amendment No. 4751), to change the enactment date, fell when McConnell (for Grassley) Amendment No. 4751 (to (the instructions) Amendment No. 4750) (listed above) fell.<P/>McConnell (for Cornyn) Amendment No. 4749 (to Amendment No. 4720), to Secure our Homeland from radical Islamists by Enhancing Law enforcement Detection (''SHIELD''), fell when Senate tabled McConnell (for Feinstein) Amendment No. 4720 (to Amendment No. 4685).

congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act_Agreement
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: Senate resumed consideration of H.R. 2578, making appropriations for the Departments of Commerce and Justice, Science, and Related Agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2016, taking action on the following amendments proposed thereto:<P/>McConnell motion to commit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions, (McConnell (for Murphy) Amendment No. 4750), to ensure that all individuals who should be prohibited from buying a firearm are listed in the national instant criminal background check system and require a background check for every firearm sale. (By 56 yeas to 42 nays (Vote No. 107), Senate tabled the motion.)<P/>McConnell (for Feinstein) Amendment No. 4720 (to Amendment No. 4685), to authorize the Attorney General to deny requests to transfer a firearm to known or suspected terrorists. (Senate tabled the amendment.)
